quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Firm Goals, Revenue, Cost, Opportunity Cost, Economic vs. Accounting Profit
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Profit Maximization, Total Revenue, Total Cost, Explicit/Implicit Costs, Opportunity Cost, Economic Profit, Accounting Profit

questions.question: Economists normally assume that the goal of a firm is to earn (i) profits as large as possible, even if it means reducing output. (ii) profits as large as possible, even if it means incurring a higher total cost. (iii) revenues as large as possible, even if it reduces profits.
questions.explanation: Firms aim to maximize profit, not revenue. Reducing output or incurring higher costs can be consistent with profit maximization if MR = MC. Pursuing maximum revenue regardless of profit is not the goal.

questions.explanation: Total cost includes all payments for inputs (fixed and variable).

Gordon is a senior majoring in computer network development at Smart State University. While he has been attending college, Gordon started a computer consulting business to help senior citizens set up their network connections and teach them how to use e-mail. Gordon charges \$25 per hour for his consulting services. Gordon also works 5 hours a week for the Economics Department to maintain that department's Web page. The Economics Department pays Gordon \$20 per hour. From this information we can conclude:
options: Gordon should increase the number of hours he works for the Economics Department to make it comparable to his consulting business income.
Gordon is obviously not maximizing his well-being if he continues to work for the Economics Department.
If Gordon chooses one hour at the beach with his friends rather than spend one more hour with a consulting client, the forgone income of \$25 is considered a cost of the choice to go to the beach.
Both b and c are correct.
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost is the value of the next best alternative foregone. Choosing the beach means giving up \$25 from consulting.

questions.question: A firm's opportunity costs of production are equal to its
options: explicit costs + implicit costs + total revenue.
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost includes all explicit payments plus implicit costs of foregone alternatives.

questions.question: John has decided to start his own lawn-mowing business. To purchase the mowers and the trailer to transport the mowers, John withdrew \$1,000 from his savings account, which was earning 3% interest, and borrowed an additional \$2,000 from the bank at an interest rate of 7%. What is John's annual opportunity cost of the financial capital that has been invested in the business?
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost = forgone interest on savings (3% of \$1,000 = \$30) + interest paid on loan (7% of \$2,000 = \$140) = \$170.

questions.question: Jane decides to open her own business and earns \$50,000 in accounting profit the first year. When deciding to open her own business, she turned down three separate job offers with annual salaries of \$30,000, \$40,000, and \$45,000. What is Jane's economic profit from running her own business?
questions.explanation: Economic profit = Accounting profit − Implicit costs. Implicit cost = highest foregone salary = \$45,000. Economic profit = \$50,000 − \$45,000 = \$5,000.

questions.question: Bev is opening her own court-reporting business. She financed the business by withdrawing money from her personal savings account. When she closed the account, the bank representative mentioned that she would have earned \$300 in interest next year. If Bev hadn’t opened her own business, she would have earned a salary of \$25,000. In her first year, Bev’s revenues were \$30,000. Which of the following statements is correct?
options: Bev’s accounting profits exceed her economic profits by \$300.
questions.explanation: Explicit costs = 0? None stated. Implicit costs = forgone salary (\$25,000) + forgone interest (\$300) = \$25,300. Accounting profit = Revenue − Explicit costs = \$30,000 − 0 = \$30,000. Economic profit = \$30,000 − \$25,300 = \$4,700.

questions.question: Dolores used to work as a high school teacher for \$40,000 per year but quit to start her own catering business. To invest, she withdrew \$20,000 from her savings (3% interest) and borrowed \$30,000 from her uncle (3% interest). Last year she paid \$25,000 for ingredients and had revenue of \$60,000. She asked Louis the accountant and Greg the economist to calculate her profit for her.
options: Louis says her costs are \$25,900, and Greg says her costs are \$66,500.
Louis says her costs are \$25,000, and Greg says her costs are \$65,000.
Louis says her profit is \$66,500, and Greg says her costs are \$66,500.
Louis says her profit is \$75,000, and Greg says her costs are \$41,500.
questions.explanation: Accountant (Louis): explicit costs = ingredients (\$25,000) + interest on loan (3% of \$30,000 = \$900) = \$25,900. Economist (Greg): total cost = explicit (\$25,900) + implicit (forgone salary \$40,000 + forgone interest on savings 3% of \$20,000 = \$600) = \$25,900 + \$40,600 = \$66,500.
